case_data.name: State of Washington v. Trump
special_collections: Trump Administration 2.0: Challenges to the Government
Trump Administration 2.0: Challenges to the Government
case_data.summary:
This lawsuit by 15 states challenges the Trump administration's use of emergency authorities to override environmental protections to permit energy projects. On Mary 9, 2025, 15 states filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington. They named President Donald Trump, the Secretary of the Army, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and its Lieutenant General, and the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation and its Vice Chair as Defendants. They challenged Executive Order 14156, which declared a national energy emergency and instructed the Defendants to issue permits and other approvals for energy-related projects on an expedited and emergency basis. The Plaintiff States argued that the executive order commanded federal agencies to disregard the law and their own regulations to fast tack extensive categories of activities that would result in significant environmental damage. They alleged that the executive order, and the agencies' issuing of permits under the order, exceeded the authority of the Executive and violated the Administrative Procedure Act. The case was assigned to District Judge Jamal N. Whitehead.

The court has requested a joint status report and proposed discovery plan from the parties by September 9, 2025. 

This case is ongoing.
case_data.summary_short: On May 9, 2025, 15 states sued the Army Corps of Engineers and other federal defendants over an executive order invoking emergency authorities to override environmental protections in order to expedite permitting of energy projects.

Case 2:25-cv-00869     Document 1     Filed 05/09/25     Page 2 of 61
 
1  The States of Washington, California, Arizona, Connecticut, Illinois, Maine, Maryland, 
2  the People of the State of Michigan,1 Minnesota, New Jersey, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, 
3  Wisconsin, and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts (Plaintiff States), bring this action to 
4  protect  the  States—including  their  citizens  and  their  natural  resources—from  the  federal 
5  government’s unlawful use of emergency permitting procedures that bypass critical ecological, 
6  historical, and cultural resource review.  
7  INTRODUCTION 
8  1.  This case concerns an Executive Order issued on January 20, 2025, EO 14156, 
9  90 Fed. Reg. 8433 (2025), entitled “Declaring a National Energy Emergency” (Executive 
10  Order).2 Despite the fact that U.S. energy production is at an all-time high, and growing, 
11  President  Trump  (the  President)  invoked  authority  under  the  National  Emergencies  Act, 
12  50 U.S.C. §§ 1601 et seq., to declare a national energy “emergency.” As relevant here, based on 
13  that declaration, the Executive Order commands the heads of executive departments and federal 
14  agencies, including the United States Army Corps of Engineers (the Corps), the Department of 
15  Interior (Interior), and the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation (ACHP), to issue permits 
16  and other approvals necessary for energy-related projects on an expedited and emergency basis.  
17  2.  The  Executive  Order  is  unlawful,  and  its  commands  that  federal  agencies 
18  disregard the law and in many cases their own regulations to fast-track extensive categories of 
19  activities  will  result  in  damage  to  waters,  wetlands,  critical  habitat,  historic  and  cultural 
20  resources, endangered species, and the people and wildlife that rely on these precious resources.  
21  3.  The Plaintiff States agree energy production, the infrastructure needed to support 
22  it, and a reliable and affordable supply of electricity are of critical importance to both the States 
23 
 
24 
1 Plaintiff People of the State of Michigan is represented by Attorney General Dana Nessel. The Attorney 
General is Michigan’s chief law enforcement officer and is authorized to bring this action on behalf of the People 
25 
of the State of Michigan pursuant to Mich. Comp. Laws § 14.28. 
2 Available at: https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/01/declaring-a-national-energy-
26 
emergency/. Attached as Exhibit A.  
 
COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY   2  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Ecology Division 
AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
1125 Washington St. SE 
P.O. Box 40100 
Olympia, WA 98504 
(360) 753-6200 
 
 

Case 2:25-cv-00869     Document 1     Filed 05/09/25     Page 3 of 61
 
1  and the Nation. The invocation of the Nation’s emergency authorities, however, is reserved for 
2  actual emergencies—not changes in Presidential policy.  
3  4.   And for good reason. The shortcuts inherent in rushing through emergency 
4  processes fundamentally undermine the rights of States. The Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C. §§ 
5  1251 et seq., for example, enshrined state rights to protect water quality within their borders. 
6  And such shortcuts, even when properly invoked, irreparably harm the states, their residents, and 
7  their environments. As a result, and for just one example, the Corps’s regulations authorize 
8  “emergency procedures” only when normal procedures would result in unacceptable hazard to 
9  human life, significant loss of property, or immediate, unforeseen, and significant economic 
10  hardship.  
11  5.  Indeed, to date, the Corps and other agencies have limited use of emergency 
12  procedures to projects necessary during or in the aftermath of natural or human-made disasters 
13  like hurricanes, flooding, or the 2010 Deepwater Horizon explosion and oil spill in the Gulf of 
14  Mexico. But now, prodded onto the shakiest of limbs by the President’s unsupported and 
15  unlawful  Executive  Order,  multiple  federal  agencies  now  seek  to  broadly  employ  these 
16  emergency procedures in non-emergency situations to, among other actions, permit discharges 
17  of dredged or fill material into waters of the United States. That unlawful process is facilitated 
18  by other agencies, like the ACHP and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, who have themselves 
19  overextended their own emergency procedures to short-change or completely skip critical 
20  environmental review under the Executive Order’s directive. 
21  6.  Unlawfully bypassing proper permitting procedures for hundreds of projects 
22  currently proposed in and around the Nation—and presumably many more in the future—will 
23  result in significant and irreparable harm to state natural and historic resources and the people 
24  and biota that rely on those resources for drinking, farming, recreating, and habitat.  
25  7.  To prevent these harms to Plaintiff States from rushed review untethered to any 
26  actual emergency, the Court should declare that the Executive Order is unlawful, that the agency 
 
COMPLAINT FOR DECLARATORY   3  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Ecology Division 
AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
1125 Washington St. SE 
P.O. Box 40100 
Olympia, WA 98504 
(360) 753-6200 
 
 

Case 2:25-cv-00869     Document 1     Filed 05/09/25     Page 4 of 61
 
1  defendants’ proposed and effectuated efforts to carry it out are arbitrary, capricious, and not in 
2  accordance with law, and enjoin any actions by the agency defendants to pursue emergency 
3  permitting for non-emergency projects. 
4  JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
5  8.  The Court has jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 1331 and 1346(a)(2). The 
6  Court has further remedial authority under the Declaratory Judgment Act, 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201(a) 
7  and 2202. The Court also has jurisdiction under the judicial-review provisions of the APA. 
8  5 U.S.C. § 702. 
9  9.  Venue is proper in this district pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1391(b)(2) and (e)(1). 
10  Defendants are United States agencies or officers sued in their official capacities. The State of 
11  Washington is a resident of this judicial district and a substantial part of the events or omissions 
12  giving rise to this Complaint occurred within the Seattle Division of the Western District of 
13  Washington. The Corps’s Seattle District, which is currently fast-tracking permitting pursuant 
14  to the Executive Order, is also located within the Seattle Division. 
15  PARTIES 
16  10.  Plaintiff States are sovereign states of the United States of America. Plaintiffs 
17  bring this action in their sovereign and proprietary capacities. As set out below, Defendants’ 
18  actions directly harm the States’ interests, including, but not limited to, environmental and 
19  financial harms that flow from the President’s unlawful declaration of an energy “emergency,” 
20  the  Corps’s  unlawful  implementation  of  the  Executive  Order  under  its  Clean  Water  Act 
21  Section 404 authority, and the ACHP’s unlawful implementation of the Executive Order under 
22  its authority under Section 106 of the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (NHPA), 54 
23  U.S.C. § 306108. The States also bring this action to protect their quasi-sovereign interests in 
24  the public health, safety, and welfare of their residents, as well as in their waters, natural 
25  resources, environment, and their economies.  
26

1  11.  Defendant Donald Trump is President of the United States. He is sued in his 
2  official capacity. 
3  12.  Defendant Daniel Driscoll is United States Secretary of the Army. He may, acting 
4  through the Army Corps’s Chief of Engineers, issue permits to discharge dredged or fill material 
5  into waters of the United States pursuant to Section 404 of the Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C. 
6  § 1344. He is sued in his official capacity.  
7  13.  Defendant Lieutenant General William H. “Butch” Graham, Jr., is Commanding 
8  General of the United States Army Corps of Engineers. He is delegated authority to issue permits 
9  to discharge dredged or fill materials into waters of the United States pursuant to Section 404 of 
10  the Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C. § 1344. He is sued in his official capacity.  
11  14.  Defendant United States Army Corps of Engineers is a branch of the United 
12  States Army. The Corps is responsible for issuing permits to discharge dredge or fill materials 
13  into waters of the United States pursuant to Section 404 of the Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C. 
14  § 1344. 
15  15.  Defendants Daniel Driscoll, Defendant Lieutenant General William H. Graham, 
16  Jr., and Defendant United States Army Corps of Engineers are collectively referred to herein as

A.  Relevant Statutory Provisions 
3  The National Emergencies Act 
4  19.  Congress enacted the National Emergencies Act (“NEA”), 50 U.S.C. §§ 1601 et 
5  seq., in 1976 to create a transparent and accountable procedure for the President’s declaration of 
6  a national emergency. 
7  20.  In  enacting  the  NEA,  Congress  recognized  that  presidents  had  overused 
8  authorities granted by Congress for quick action in situations where Congress lacked adequate 
9  time to act. The primary purpose of the NEA was to prevent the President from exercising 
10  unbounded  authority  to  declare  states  of  emergency  and  continue  them  in  perpetuity. 
11  Accordingly, the NEA terminated then-existing declared emergencies (some having persisted 
12  for decades) and created a new legal framework to cabin the President’s emergency authority.  
13  21.  Specifically, the NEA was intended to ensure that presidential emergency powers 
14  would “be utilized only when emergencies actually exist.” S. Rep. No. 94-1168, at 2 (1976). 
15  Senator Frank Church, who was instrumental in developing the NEA, testified on legislation that 
16  became the NEA that “the President should not be allowed to invoke emergency authorities or 
17  in any way utilize the provisions of this Act for frivolous or partisan matters, nor for that matter 
18  in cases where important but not ‘essential’ problems are at stake.” Hearing on H.R. 3884 Before 
19  the S. Comm. of Governmental Operations, 94th Cong. 7 (1976). Senator Church further 
20  explained that “[t]he Committee intentionally chose language which would make clear that the 
21  authority of the Act was to be reserved for matters that are ‘essential’ to the protection of the 
22  Constitution and the people.” Id. 
23  22.  Under the NEA, the President may only invoke the emergency powers Congress 
24  has authorized in other federal statutes when there is a national emergency. 50 U.S.C. § 1621(a) 
25  (“With respect to Acts of Congress authorizing the exercise, during the period of a national 
26  emergency, of any special or extraordinary power, the President is authorized to declare such a

1  national emergency”). As the Ninth Circuit recognized, the NEA does not enlarge the powers of 
2  the Executive Branch beyond authorities in existing statutes and regulations. Sierra Club v. 
3  Trump, 977 F.3d 853, 864–65 (9th Cir. 2020), vacated on other grounds, Biden v. Sierra Club, 
4  142 S. Ct. 56 (2021).  
5  23.  The NEA  further requires the President  to specify the statutory emergency 
6  authorities he or she intends to invoke upon declaring a national emergency, and to publish the 
7  proclamation of a national emergency in the Federal Register and transmit it to Congress. Id. 
8  “When the President declares a national emergency, no powers or authorities made available by 
9  statute for use in the event of an emergency shall be exercised unless and until the President 
10  specifies the provisions of law under which he proposes that he, or other offices will act. Such 
11  specification may be made either in the declaration of a national emergency, or by one or more 
12  contemporaneous  or  subsequent  executive  orders  published  in  the  Federal  Register  and 
13  transmitted to Congress.” 50 U.S.C.§ 1631. 
14  24.  Congress  has  specifically  authorized  the  use  of  emergency  powers  by  the 
15  Executive Branch upon declaration of a national emergency and has provided the parameters of 
16  such emergency powers in numerous statutes. For example, 10 U.S.C. § 2808(a) provides, “[i]n 
17  the event of a declaration. . . by the President of a national emergency in accordance with the 
18  National Emergencies Act (50 U.S.C. §§ 1601 et seq.) that requires use of the armed forces, the 
19  Secretary of Defense, without regard to any other provision of law, may undertake military 
20  construction projects.” Similarly, 50 U.S.C. § 1515 provides, “[a]fter [the effective date], the 
21  operation of this section. . . or any portion thereof, may be suspended by the President during 
22  the period of . . . any national emergency declared by Congress or by the President.”

25  physical, and biological integrity of the Nation’s waters.” 33 U.S.C. § 1251(a).

1  26.  To achieve that goal, Clean Water Act Section 301(a), 33 U.S.C. § 1311(a), 
2  prohibits the discharge of any pollutant by any person into waters of the United States unless 
3  that discharge is authorized by a permit issued under, inter alia, Clean Water Act Section 404, 
4  33 U.S.C. § 1344. 
5  27.  Clean Water Act Section 404(a) authorizes the Secretary of the Army, acting 
6  through the Chief of Engineers of the Corps, to issue permits to discharge dredged or fill material 
7  into navigable waters at specified disposal sites. 33 U.S.C. § 1344(a). 
8  28.  Each disposal site must be specified for each permit through application of and 
9  compliance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) Section 404(b)(1) 
10  Guidelines, 40 C.F.R. Part 230. See 33 U.S.C. § 1344(b)(1). 
11  29.  The  Corps  has  promulgated  regulations  governing  its  process  to  review 
12  applications for and issue Clean Water Act Section 404 permits. See generally 33 C.F.R. §§ 320, 
13  323, 325.  
14  30.  The Corps’s standard procedures for processing a Section 404 permit application 
15  are set out in 33 C.F.R § 325.2(a). For discharges requiring a standard permit (i.e., an individual 
16  permit), the Corps receives a permit application,3 and if/when the application is complete, issues 
17  a public notice of the application soliciting comments from the public, adjacent property owners, 
18  interested groups and individuals, local agencies, state agencies, and federal agencies. The Corps 
19  considers all comments and the applicant’s responses to those comments, if any, and determines 
20  whether the proposed project will require either an Environmental Assessment or, if there are 
21  significant environmental impacts, an Environmental Impact Statement under the National 
22  Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). See 33 C.F.R § 325.2(a)(1)–(5). These processes ensure that 
23  the Corps fully considers the project’s environmental impacts and reasonable alternatives before 
24  making a decision.

24  Corps proposes issuing state, regional, or nationwide permits (collectively, general permits), the

26  determine environmental effects and uses procedures similar to those used during the standard

1  61.  The Clean Water Act’s only “Emergency Powers” provision authorizes the EPA 
2  Administrator to “bring suit on behalf of the United States . . . to immediately restrain any person 
3  causing or contributing” to pollution “presenting an imminent and substantial endangerment to 
4  the health . . . or to the welfare of persons where such endangerment is to the livelihood of such 
5  persons, such as inability to market shellfish, to stop the discharge of pollutants causing or 
6  contributing to such pollution or to take such other action as may be necessary.” See 33 U.S.C. 
7  § 1364. This statutory language demonstrates that Congress contemplated the potential need for 
8  emergency action under the Clean Water Act and expressly authorized only those powers it 
9  thought necessary. Importantly, the emergency powers Congress granted are for the purpose of 
10  protecting waters of the United States and furthering the Clean Water Act’s goals.

1  Interior’s Emergency Procedures 
2  78.  Interior’s “emergency responses” authority only allows circumventing standard 
3  NEPA procedures with regard to actions needed to control the immediate impacts of threat to 
4  life, property, or important resources. 
5  79.  Interior has adopted regulations governing the use of emergency authority in the 
6  preparation of a NEPA analysis and documentation. 43 C.F.R. § 46.150. These provisions allow 
7  designated Interior Responsible Officials to “determine that an emergency exists that makes it 
8  necessary  to  take  urgently  needed  actions  before  preparing  a  NEPA  analysis  and 
9  documentation.” 43 C.F.R. § 46.150. The regulations effectively bypass Interior’s otherwise 
10  applicable responsibility to comply with NEPA prior to undertaking agency action. 
11  80.  This authority is highly circumscribed, applying only to “those actions necessary 
12  to control the immediate impacts of the emergency that are urgently needed to mitigate harm to 
13  life, property, or important natural, cultural, or historic resources.” 43 C.F.R. § 46.150(a). In 
14  these  limited  circumstances,  Responsible  Officials  must  “take  into  account  the  probable 
15  environmental consequences of [actions taken in response to an emergency] and mitigate 
16  foreseeable adverse environmental effects to the extent practical.” Id. (emphasis added). 
17  81.  The regulations further require the Responsible Official to “document in writing 
18  the determination that an emergency exists and describe the responsive action(s) taken at the 
19  time the emergency [i.e., urgently needed actions to mitigate harm to life, property, or important 
20  natural, cultural, or historic resources] exists.” 43 C.F.R. § 46.150(a)-(b).  
21  82.  If further emergency actions are required following those needed to control the 
22  immediate impacts of  a threat  to life, property, or important  natural,  cultural, or historic 
23  resources, the regulations contemplate two paths. 43 C.F.R. § 46.150(c)-(d).  
24  83.  Where such follow-on actions are not likely to have significant environmental 
25  impacts, the Responsible Official must document that determination “in an environmental 
26  assessment and a finding of no significant impact . . . unless categorically excluded.” 43 C.F.R.

2  90.  The ACHP has adopted regulations regarding the application of Section 106 of 
3  the NHPA during emergency situations. 36 C.F.R. § 800.12. ACHP’s emergency procedures are

6  91.  The ACHP’s regulations first encourage federal agency officials, in consultation 
7  with appropriate state and tribal historic preservation officers  and the ACHP, to develop 
8  procedures for taking historic resources into account during an emergency. Such procedures only 
9  purport to apply to “operations which respond to a disaster or emergency declared by the

11  threats to life or property.” 36 C.F.R. § 800.12(a) (emphasis added). These procedures must be 
12  approved by the ACHP before being applied. Id.

15  programmatic agreement . . . that contains specific provisions for dealing with historic properties 
16  in emergency situations; or (2) Notifying [the ACHP], the appropriate [state or tribal historic

18  religious and cultural significance to historic properties likely to be affected prior to the 
19  undertaking and affording them an opportunity to comment within seven days of notification” 
20  unless circumstances do not permit seven days. 36 C.F.R. § 800.12(b)(1)-(2). These procedures 
21  are limited to “emergency undertaking[s] as an essential and immediate response to a disaster or 
22  emergency declared by the President, a tribal government, or the Governor of a State or another 
23  immediate threat to life or property.” 36 C.F.R. § 800.12(b) (emphasis added).

C.  The President Declares a National “Energy Emergency” Despite the Absence of 
Any Emergency 
4 
5  94.  The President issued Executive Order 14156 on January 20, 2025—day one of 
6  his new Administration. The Executive Order declares a national energy emergency pursuant to 
7  the NEA, 50 U.S.C. §§ 1601 et seq. But the circumstances described in the Executive Order do 
8  not meet even an expansive definition of the term “emergency.” 
9  95.  The Executive Order’s emergency declaration claims a need to remediate an 
10  alleged shortage of energy supplies and shore up an “unreliable” grid to meet the Nation’s needs. 
11  It provides no support for these assertions. It also irrationally proposes actions antithetical to 
12  those alleged needs.  
13  96.  The Executive Order asserts that “energy and critical minerals [] identification, 
14  leasing, development, production, transportation, refining, and generation capacity of the United 
15  States are all far too inadequate to meet our Nation’s needs.” 90 Fed. Reg. 8433 (2025). The 
16  Executive Order’s emergency declaration cites no facts or evidence to support these claims, nor 
17  could it, as domestic energy production is at an all time high and the U.S. is a net-exporter of 
18  energy products. 
19  97.  The  Executive  Order  further  asserts  that  “precariously  inadequate  and 
20  intermittent energy supply, and an increasingly unreliable grid, require swift and decisive action” 
21  and  that  “[w]ithout  immediate  remedy,  [the]  situation  will  dramatically  deteriorate.”  The 
22  Executive Order’s emergency declaration cites no facts or evidence to support these claims, nor 
23  could it.  
24  98.  Plaintiff States fully support taking appropriate action to ensure a reliable grid 
25  that provides all Americans with affordable energy but, simply put, there is no basis for the 
26  President’s emergency declaration. To the extent they have any merit, concerns about the current

6  Nation’s  goal  of  promoting  reliable,  diverse,  and  affordable  energy.  Burning  fossil  fuels

8  infrastructure and threaten human life. Experts agree that extreme weather fueled by climate

12  sources such as solar and wind enhances grid reliability. Wind and solar are also essential to 
13  bolstering local energy generation in regions of the country that do not have abundant fossil fuel 
14  resources. Because fossil fuels must be transported to these regions from other parts of the 
15  country, they are often exposed to the price volatility and reliability risks inherent in purchasing 
16  fuel on an open market. Renewables help to moderate this risk by generating electricity using 
17  locally available resources—wind and solar power.

1  210.  A court reviewing executive action has an independent duty to determine what 
2  the law is and whether executive officers invoking statutory authority exceed their statutory 
3  power. See Armstrong v. Exceptional Child Ctr., Inc., 575 U.S. 320, 326 (2015).  
4  211.  Courts may review a presidential Executive Order and are empowered to enjoin 
5  officers of the Executive Branch from obeying illegal Presidential commands, and may enjoin 
6  ultra vires acts, that is, acts exceeding the officers’ purported statutory authority. Chamber of 
7  Commerce v. Reich, 74 F.3d 1322, 1328 (D.C. Cir. 1996); Sierra Club v. Trump, 379 F. Supp. 
8  3d 883, 909–11 (N.D. Cal. 2019), vacated on other grounds, Biden v. Sierra Club, 142 S. Ct. 56 
9  (2021). 
10  212.  The NEA only allows the President to unlock emergency powers that Congress 
11  authorized in other statutes. It does not create new emergency powers or enlarge existing ones. 
12  See 50 U.S.C. § 1621(a).  
13  213.  The NEA requires the President to specify the statutory provisions of law under 
14  which he proposes that he or his officers will act before any emergency authority may be 
15  exercised. 50 U.S.C. § 1631. 
16  214.  While the President purported to specify the statutory provisions of law under 
17  which he proposes that he or his officers will act, none of those provisions provide the President 
18  or any agency with emergency powers or authorities upon a declaration of a national energy 
19  emergency under the NEA as set out in the Executive Order.  
20  215.  The President has acted ultra vires by directing agencies to invoke emergency 
21  procedures to evade or shorten technical and/or environmental review under circumstances 
22  that—as a matter of law—do not qualify as an emergency under applicable statutory and 
23  regulatory provisions.  
24  216.  The Corps has acted contrary to law and ultra vires by, among other things, 
25  implementing the Executive Order’s directive to issue Clean Water Act Section 404 permits on 
26  an expedited or emergency.

8  COUNT 3 
Violation of the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. § 706 – Arbitrary and Capricious 
9 
(Against Corps Defendants) 
10  228.  Plaintiff States reallege and incorporate by reference the allegations set forth in 
11  each of the preceding paragraphs.  
12  229.  The Corps is an “agency” as defined in 5 U.S.C. § 551(1).  
13  230.  The APA provides that this Court “shall” “hold unlawful and set aside” agency 
14  action that is “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or not otherwise in accordance with 
15  law.” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). 
16  231.  Agency action is arbitrary and capricious if the agency fails to consider important 
17  factors, considers issues that Congress did not intend for it to consider, or fails to articulate a 
18  reasoned explanation for the action. 
19  232.  When the Corps invoked emergency procedures to permit projects under Clean 
20  Water Act Section 404, 33 U.S.C. § 1344, it was required to consider the objective of the Clean 
21  Water Act. 
22  233.  The Clean  Water Act’s objective is to “restore and maintain the chemical, 
23  physical, and biological integrity of the Nation’s waters.” 33 U.S.C. § 1251(a).  
24  234.  The protection of water quality is the paramount interest the Corps must consider 
25  when executing its permitting authority under Clean Water Act Section 404.
